The earely Houres were readie to unlocke </br>The doore of Morne, to let abroad the Day, </br>When sad Ocyroe sitting on a rocke, </br>Hemmd in with teares, not glassing as they say </br>Shee woont, her damaske beuties (when to play </br>Shee bent her looser fancie) in the streame, </br>That sudding on the rocke, would closely seeme </br>To imitate her whitenesse with his frothy creame.

But hanging from the stone her carefull head, </br>That shewed (for griefe had made it so to shew) </br>A stone it selfe, thus onely differed, </br>That those without, these streames within did flow, </br>Both ever ranne, yet never lesse did grow, </br>And tearing from her head her amber haires, </br>Whose like or none, or onely Phaebus weares, </br>Shee strowd there on the flood to waite upon her teares.

About her many Nymphes sate weeping by, </br>That when shee sang were woont to daunce and leape.</br>And all the grasse that round about did lie, </br>Hung full of teares, as if that meant to weepe, </br>Whilest, th' undersliding streames did softly creepe,</br>And clung about the rocke with winding wreath, </br>To heare a Canto of Elizaes death: </br>Which thus poore nymph shee sung, whilest sorrowe lent her breath.

Tell me ye blushing currols that bunch out, </br>To cloath with beuteous red your ragged sire, </br>So let the sea-greene mosse curle round about </br>With soft embrace (as creeping vines doe wyre </br>Their loved Elmes) your sides in rosie tyre, </br>So let the ruddie vermeyle of your cheeke </br>Make staind carnations fresher liveries seeke, </br>So let your braunched armes grow crooked, smooth, and sleeke.

So from your growth late be you rent away, </br>And hung with silver bels and whistles shrill, </br>Unto those children be you given to play </br>Where blest Eliza raignd:  so never ill </br>Betide your canes nor them with breaking spill, </br>Tell me if some uncivill hand should teare </br>Your branches hence, and place them otherwhere; </br>Could you still grow, and such fresh crimson ensignes beare?

Tell me sad Philomele that yonder sit'st </br>Piping thy songs unto the dauncing twig, </br>And to the waters fall thy musicke fit'st, </br>So let the friendly prickle never digge </br>Thy watchfull breast with wound or small or bigge, </br>Whereon thou lean'st, so let the hissing snake </br>Sliding with shrinking silence never take </br>Th' unwarie foote, whilst thou perhaps hangst halfe awake.

So let the loathed lapwing when her nest </br>Is stolne away, not as shee uses, flie, </br>Cousening the searcher of his promisd feast, </br>But widdowd of all hope still Itis crie, </br>And nought but Itis, Itis, till shee die. </br>Say sweetest querister of the airie quire </br>Doth not thy Tereu, Tereu then expire, </br>When winter robs thy house of all her greene attire?

Tell me ye velvet headed violets </br>That fringe the crooked banke with gawdie blewe, </br>So let with comely grace your prettie frets </br>Be spread, so let a thousand Zephyrs sue </br>To kisse your willing heads, that seeme t'eschew </br>Their wanton touch with maiden modestie, </br>So let the silver dewe but lightly lie </br>Like little watrie worlds within your azure skie,

So when your blazing leaves are broadly spread </br>Let wandring nymphes gather you in their lapps, </br>And send you where Eliza lieth dead, </br>To strow the sheete that her pale bodie wraps, </br>Aie me in this I envie your good haps: </br>Who would not die, there to be buried? </br>Say if the sunne denie his beames to shedde </br>Upon your living stalkes, grow you not withered?

Tell me thou wanton brooke, that slip'st away </br>T'avoid the straggling bankes still flowing cling, </br>So let thy waters cleanely tribute pay </br>Unmixt with mudde unto the sea your king, </br>So never let your streames leave murmuring </br>Untill they steale by many a secret furt </br>To kisse those walls that built Elizaes court, </br>Drie you not when your mother springs are choakt with durt?

Yes you all say, and I say with you all, </br>Naught without cause of joy can joyous bide, </br>Then me unhappie nymph whome the dire fall </br>Of my joyes spring, But there aye me shee cried, </br>And spake no more, for sorrow speech denied. </br>And downe into her watrie lodge did goe; </br>The very waters when shee sunke did showe </br>With many wrinckled ohs they sympathiz'd her woe.

The sunne in mourning cloudes inveloped </br>Flew fast into the westearne world to tell </br>News of her death.  Heaven it selfe sorrowed </br>With teares that to the earthes danke bosome fell; </br>But when the next Aurora gan to deale </br>Handfuls of roses fore the teame of day </br>A sheapheard drove his flocke by chance that way </br>And made the nymph to dance that mourned yesterday.</br>
